profiles:
Summary My areas of expertise encompass food production systems and land use/land cover changes. I investigate the drivers of environmental change and the impact of land management on the delivery of ecosystem services. 
• Background in environmental sciences and policy, with a focus on sustainable agriculture and ecosystem services 
• Conducted field research on management practices in export crops in Costa Rica  
• Extensive experience with interview studies (over 400 interviews with farmers and others working in agriculture) and field sampling (avian, insect, water and soil sampling) 
• Diverse teaching and curriculum development experiences

 Experience Program director Stanford University, School of Earth, Energy and Environmental Sciences June 2014  – Present (1 year 3 months) Stanford, CA Implementing a teaching programme in Stanford’s School of Earth Sciences. Wrote the project proposal to secure funding from the National Science Foundation. Initiated contact with local minority serving institutions and 2-year colleges and recruited faculty interested in participating in InTeGrate. Recruited postdoctoral and advanced graduate students at Stanford to teach modules in the faculties’ courses. Organized a 2-day workshop for postdoctoral and graduate students to learn about science pedagogy and to receive training in the modules. Created assessment tools to measure the immediate impact of the programme, as well as to garner feedback on how to improve the programme in its second pilot year. Managing the programme budget. Postdoctoral researcher Stanford University 2012  – Present (3 years) Dept of Environmental and Earth System Science/Woods Institute for the Environme Independent researcher, satellite image interpretation, data collection, interviews, spatial analysis, collaborate with other researchers both at Stanford and in Costa Rica. Research project uses socio-economic data, data on land use/land cover and biodiversity and provision of ecosystem services data to develop scenarios for land use trajectories in order to identify policy options to balance human well-being and ecosystem integrity. Postdoctoral fellow Stockholm Resilience Centre 2012  – Present (3 years) Stockholm, Sweden Independent researcher, satellite image interpretation, data collection, interviews, spatial analysis, collaborate with other researchers both at Stanford and in Costa Rica. Research project uses socio-economic data, data on land use/land cover and biodiversity and provision of ecosystem services data to develop scenarios for land use trajectories in order to identify policy options to balance human well-being and ecosystem integrity. Lecturer and admissions counselor Stanford University, Summer Institute February 2013  –  August 2014  (1 year 7 months) Stanford University Reviewed +400 applications each year for admission to the Summer Institute’s Environmental Science course at Stanford. Independently developed curriculum for the 3-week module (35 hours lecture and 35 hours lab/activity) and taught the module for two years. Managed the budget for the module and was responsible for 3 teaching assistants.  Member of Advisory Committee Centre for Transdisciplinary Environmental Research, Stockholm University May 2005  –  December 2011  (6 years 8 months) Stockholm, Sweden Met monthly with PhD students from all other faculties in the University to discuss transdisciplinary approaches to environmental problems, collaborations and plan outreach activities on campus such as seminars, modules and lectures. Science Editor International Geosphere Biosphere Program, Swedish Royal Academy of Sciences March 2002  –  June 2003  (1 year 4 months) Stockholm, Sweden Wrote and edited science publication synthesizing the previous 10 years of global change research. Served as liaison with other contributing scientists. Edited newsletter and Science Series publications. Research Consultant World Bank January 2000  –  June 2001  (1 year 6 months) Washington DC I researched the economic viability of organic agriculture on the world market and more specifically examined the possibilities of promoting organic agriculture in Cuba. Responsibilities included traveling to Cuba and meeting with representatives from different organizations within the food sector.

Summary To use my dynamic skill set of people skills, quantitative experience, and computer know how to have a career in education and student service. I've spent the past 8+ years working with high school and college students in multiple capacities, most specifically: 
 
- Mentoring and advising high school students towards college success 
- Helping college students with career goals and transitioning from college to the workforce Specialties:College Advising, Academic Advising, Data Analysis, Visual Communication Summary To use my dynamic skill set of people skills, quantitative experience, and computer know how to have a career in education and student service. - Mentoring and advising high school students towards college success 
- Helping college students with career goals and transitioning from college to the workforce Specialties:College Advising, Academic Advising, Data Analysis, Visual Communication Experience Admissions Counselor Stanford University August 2014  – Present (1 year 1 month) Reporting to an Assistant Dean of Admission, the Admission Counselor is an integral member of the admission staff charged with recruiting, selecting, and yielding the freshman/transfer classes. 
 
Responsibilities include: serving in a public relations/informational role with prospective applicants, their parents and high school guidance counselors; participating in the reading process; traveling to convey information about the admission process at regional events and school visits to identify/recruit applicants; managing a specific reading territory; and developing collegial relationships with school personnel in those areas. College Access & Success Manager East Bay College Fund August 2013  –  August 2014  (1 year 1 month) oakland, ca The College Access & Success Manager is responsible for development, coordination, and maintaining records of our access services for our K-12 program and Bridge support for our first year college students. 
 
Responsibilities include: 
• Coordinate the EBCF Access Programs at school sites in OUSD 
• Increase the number of students applying for college, FAFSA, our scholarship, and Crews 
• Coordination of Scholar Selection Process for the EBCF Scholarships and integrating scholarship into school access services  
• Coordinate and direct college advising service for EBCF Summer Programs (shared) 
• Provide support services to a cohort of EBCF freshman college Scholars.  
• Coordinate some and support all EBCF Scholar events. 
• Coordinate and support some College Crews. College Access Program Manager BUILD July 2012  –  August 2013  (1 year 2 months) Oakland, CA The College Access Program Manager (CAPM) ensures that all BUILD students get the academic supports and counseling to ensure they are on track to graduate from high school and will be eligible-and-competitive for college. The CAPM will work with school counselors, teachers and outside resources to accomplish this goal. Additionally, the CAPM will counsel, advise and collaborate with all program managers to ensure that all 9th-12th grade students are on track to meet high school graduation and college eligibility requirements. 
 
Responsibilities include: 
•	Creating & maintaining student relationships 
•	Developing student academic skills through Academic Counseling that will enable them to be successful in post secondary education  
•	Managing the Academic Support Center and BUILD's academic support program  
•	Planning and implementing student academic improvement and support plans through transcript reviews and 1-on-1 check-ins 
•	Collecting and analyzing program evaluations and student outcome data to make program recommendations for current and future program years 
•	Planning and executing student annual events and celebrations 
•	Managing the College Access Program Budget 
•	Managing relationships with schools, parents, mentors and universities 
•	Implementing SAT and ACT preparation programs  
•	Training and managing College Access Coordinators, Lead Tutors and any other Interns that enable the individual supports to each student. Academic Program Manager, Oakland BUILD August 2010  –  June 2012  (1 year 11 months) San Francisco Bay Area The Academic Program Manager (APM) is a critical player at BUILD and is responsible for the academic success of all students in the BUILD Youth Business Incubator (10th-11th grades). The APM ensures that Incubator students consistently improve academically, are on track to graduate from high school and will be eligible and/or eligible-and-competitive for 4-yr college/university. 
 
- Provided space for tutoring and academic support for high school students 
- Planned and implemented college tours in the Bay Area and Southern California 
- Recruited, trained and managed academic tutors to deliver content assistance to students. 
- Reviewed student transcripts and develop academic plans 
- Collaborated with HS teachers/counselors. 
- Met with students and their families to develop academic improvement plans and to encourage success 
- Managed SAT/ACT preparation program, Campus Recruitment Manager Citizen Schools August 2008  –  July 2010  (2 years) San Francisco Bay Area Campus Recruitment Managers are part of a team responsible for the sourcing and hiring of front line program staff (National Teaching Fellows and Team Leaders) and select volunteers (Citizen Teachers) for sites across Citizen Schools’ national network. 
 
The Campus Recruitment Manager develops and leads the execution of aggressive recruitment plans in their regions and collaborate closely with both their CRM peers and local state office staff, including the Talent Managers, Program Directors and State Directors. Through the use of effective marketing techniques, hands-on relationship management, and other innovative recruitment tools, CRMs lead Citizen Schools in a multi-layered recruitment approach to colleges and universities in search of the most talented and committed young people to join our movement. CRMs also train local state office and program staff on recruitment and hiring techniques and coordinate the on-boarding of new staff with the National Program Department and state office staff. In addition, the CRM may manage part-time staff resources, including Teaching Fellows, Team Leaders and university-based Campus Coordinators (paid interns). Marketing & Development Coordinator Westside Community Services May 2007  –  April 2008  (1 year) San Francisco Bay Area - Developed new marketing and promotional materials to cater to current and potential funders 
- Coordinated grant development activities under direction of Deputy Director 
- Researched and located new vendors; reduced department marketing costs by 50% 
- Created and organized development file database 
- Planned and coordinated sponsorship events marketed to funders, supporters, and partners 
- Coordinated and performed outreach to potential funders Account Coordinator/Jr. Designer e-agency June 2006  –  April 2007  (11 months) San Francisco Bay Area - Developed and maintained websites and marketing materials 
- Specialized in providing excellent customer service for diverse clientele 
- Oversaw all print production schedules with extreme detail  
- Managed all client related technical support inquiries  
- Collaborated with other designers to pitch ideas to current and potential clients

College Access Program Manager BUILD July 2012  –  August 2013  (1 year 2 months) Oakland, CA The College Access Program Manager (CAPM) ensures that all BUILD students get the academic supports and counseling to ensure they are on track to graduate from high school and will be eligible-and-competitive for college. The CAPM will work with school counselors, teachers and outside resources to accomplish this goal. Additionally, the CAPM will counsel, advise and collaborate with all program managers to ensure that all 9th-12th grade students are on track to meet high school graduation and college eligibility requirements. 
 
Responsibilities include: 
•	Creating & maintaining student relationships 
•	Developing student academic skills through Academic Counseling that will enable them to be successful in post secondary education  
•	Managing the Academic Support Center and BUILD's academic support program  
•	Planning and implementing student academic improvement and support plans through transcript reviews and 1-on-1 check-ins 
•	Collecting and analyzing program evaluations and student outcome data to make program recommendations for current and future program years 
•	Planning and executing student annual events and celebrations 
•	Managing the College Access Program Budget 
•	Managing relationships with schools, parents, mentors and universities 
•	Implementing SAT and ACT preparation programs  
•	Training and managing College Access Coordinators, Lead Tutors and any other Interns that enable the individual supports to each student. Academic Program Manager, Oakland BUILD August 2010  –  June 2012  (1 year 11 months) San Francisco Bay Area The Academic Program Manager (APM) is a critical player at BUILD and is responsible for the academic success of all students in the BUILD Youth Business Incubator (10th-11th grades). The APM ensures that Incubator students consistently improve academically, are on track to graduate from high school and will be eligible and/or eligible-and-competitive for 4-yr college/university. 
 
- Provided space for tutoring and academic support for high school students 
- Planned and implemented college tours in the Bay Area and Southern California 
- Recruited, trained and managed academic tutors to deliver content assistance to students. 
- Reviewed student transcripts and develop academic plans 
- Collaborated with HS teachers/counselors. 
- Met with students and their families to develop academic improvement plans and to encourage success

- Managed SAT/ACT preparation program, Campus Recruitment Manager Citizen Schools August 2008  –  July 2010  (2 years) San Francisco Bay Area Campus Recruitment Managers are part of a team responsible for the sourcing and hiring of front line program staff (National Teaching Fellows and Team Leaders) and select volunteers (Citizen Teachers) for sites across Citizen Schools’ national network. 
 
The Campus Recruitment Manager develops and leads the execution of aggressive recruitment plans in their regions and collaborate closely with both their CRM peers and local state office staff, including the Talent Managers, Program Directors and State Directors. Through the use of effective marketing techniques, hands-on relationship management, and other innovative recruitment tools, CRMs lead Citizen Schools in a multi-layered recruitment approach to colleges and universities in search of the most talented and committed young people to join our movement. CRMs also train local state office and program staff on recruitment and hiring techniques and coordinate the on-boarding of new staff with the National Program Department and state office staff. In addition, the CRM may manage part-time staff resources, including Teaching Fellows, Team Leaders and university-based Campus Coordinators (paid interns). Campus Recruitment Manager Citizen Schools August 2008  –  July 2010  (2 years) San Francisco Bay Area Campus Recruitment Managers are part of a team responsible for the sourcing and hiring of front line program staff (National Teaching Fellows and Team Leaders) and select volunteers (Citizen Teachers) for sites across Citizen Schools’ national network. 
 
The Campus Recruitment Manager develops and leads the execution of aggressive recruitment plans in their regions and collaborate closely with both their CRM peers and local state office staff, including the Talent Managers, Program Directors and State Directors. Through the use of effective marketing techniques, hands-on relationship management, and other innovative recruitment tools, CRMs lead Citizen Schools in a multi-layered recruitment approach to colleges and universities in search of the most talented and committed young people to join our movement. CRMs also train local state office and program staff on recruitment and hiring techniques and coordinate the on-boarding of new staff with the National Program Department and state office staff. In addition, the CRM may manage part-time staff resources, including Teaching Fellows, Team Leaders and university-based Campus Coordinators (paid interns).
